question: A 64-year-old man presents to the emergency room with a headache and nausea. He reports that he was rocking his grandson to sleep when the symptoms began. He states the pain is constant and is primarily located on his right side. When asked to indicate the area of pain, he says that it surrounds his eye and upper forehead. He had one episode of vomiting. The patient also reports difficulty seeing out of his right eye, which he attributes to excessive tearing. The patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 135/91 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 12/min. The patient’s right eye is shown in Figure A. Upon physical examination, the right pupil is minimally responsive to light and the globe feels firm. A right-sided carotid bruit is appreciated. Which of the following is the most appropriate prophylaxis for this patient’s condition?
reason:
This patient is presenting with sudden-onset unilateral vision loss and an orbitofrontal headache with a dilated pupil and a hard ocular globe suggesting a diagnosis of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Long-term management of angle-closure glaucoma can include acetazolamide.

Examination of the eye in a patient with acute-closure glaucoma will reveal a red eye that is rock-hard and a mid-dilated pupil which is minimally reactive to light. The fundoscopic exam will show an increased optic cup-to-disk ratio (>0.4) and tonometry will show increased intraocular pressure. Gonioscopy is the diagnostic gold standard. Acute treatment and long-term management involve the administration of beta-blockers, alpha-2-agonists, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors such as acetazolamide to decrease intraocular pressure. The definitive treatment is iridotomy.

Airaksinen et al. review the treatment of closed-angle glaucoma. They discuss how a combination of acetazolamide and beta-blockers can terminate an attack. They recommend using 1 drop of pilocarpine 3 hours after intravenous acetazolamide administration.

Figure/Illustration A is a clinical photograph showing an eye with injected conjunctiva (red circles) and a mid-dilated pupil. These findings are consistent with angle-closure glaucoma.

Incorrect Answers:
Answer B: Amitriptyline can be used as prophylaxis for migraines. Migraines present as unilateral, pulsating headaches that may be associated with nausea or photophobia. Patients with migraines can sometimes experience an aura with visual field changes; however, they would not have exam findings of a rock-hard eye or injection.

Answer C: Clopidogrel may be used as a conservative treatment for carotid atherosclerosis, which can be an embolic source for central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). CRAO presents as acute, painless, monocular vision loss. A fundoscopic exam will demonstrate ischemia of the retina.

Answer D: Epinephrine is contraindicated in the treatment of angle-closure glaucoma as it increases pupillary dilation. It is used in the management of open-angle glaucoma. This would present with gradually patchy loss of vision and is generally painless.

Answer E: Verapamil is used as prophylaxis for cluster headaches. Cluster headaches present as unilateral, repetitive, brief headaches associated with severe peri-orbital pain, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and Horner syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

Bullet Summary:
Pharmacologic management of acute angle-closure glaucoma involves beta-blockers, alpha-2 agonists, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.
raw_responses:
Step 1: Analyze the clinical presentation.
• The patient is a 64‐year‐old man with a sudden, constant headache focused around his right eye and upper forehead. He also has nausea and vomiting.
• He reports difficulty seeing from the right eye with excessive tearing.
• The exam reveals that the right globe is “firm” (suggesting increased intraocular pressure) and the right pupil is minimally reactive to light. Although a right‐sided carotid bruit is noted, this is most likely an incidental finding in a patient with hypertension and atherosclerotic disease.

Step 2: Determine the diagnosis.
• The constellation of periorbital/forehead pain, ocular symptoms (tearing, decreased visual acuity), a firm globe on palpation, and a poorly reactive pupil is highly suggestive of acute angle closure glaucoma. This condition leads to a rapid rise in intraocular pressure causing the eye to feel firm, and can also produce nausea and vomiting.
• (Note: Cluster headaches can also cause periorbital pain and lacrimation; however, the firm globe and decreased pupillary reactivity are not features of cluster headaches.)

Step 3: Identify the appropriate prophylactic/therapeutic measure.
• In acute angle closure glaucoma, the goal is to rapidly lower intraocular pressure and prevent further damage to the optic nerve. Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, is a mainstay of initial management because it reduces the production of aqueous humor.
• Although definitive prophylaxis for future episodes often involves procedures such as laser peripheral iridotomy, among the medication options provided, acetazolamide is the one indicated for decreasing intraocular pressure and thereby helping prevent recurrence.

Step 4: Compare and eliminate the other options.
• Amitriptyline is used for migraine prophylaxis.
• Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent used in cerebrovascular disease.
• Epinephrine is not used in this setting.
• Verapamil is used for cluster headache prophylaxis.
• None of these address the pathophysiology of increased intraocular pressure seen in angle closure glaucoma.

Final Answer: A. Acetazolamide.

Step 1: Examine key features in the history and exam.

• The patient is a 64‐year‐old man with a headache that started while he was rocking his grandson. The headache is constant, unilateral (right side), and located around the eye and upper forehead.
• There is associated nausea with one episode of vomiting.
• The patient also reports difficulty with vision on the affected side, which he attributes to excessive tearing.
• On exam, the right eye shows a minimally responsive pupil and is described as “firm” on palpation. A right‐sided carotid bruit is noted.

Step 2: Consider the differential diagnosis.

• Although some findings (e.g., eye pain, nausea/vomiting, visual changes, and autonomic features such as tearing) might be seen in acute angle-closure glaucoma, the fact that the question is asking for prophylaxis (i.e., prevention of recurrent episodes) makes this less likely. Acute angle-closure glaucoma is managed emergently (first with agents such as acetazolamide, pilocarpine, etc.) and then definitively with a laser peripheral iridotomy, but none of these options are listed.
• The features of unilateral pain around the eye/forehead with associated lacrimation (tearing) and autonomic dysfunction are strongly consistent with a cluster headache. Cluster headaches are known for their severe unilateral periorbital pain accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (e.g., lacrimation, conjunctival injection, and sometimes a mildly altered pupillary response).

Step 3: Match the prophylactic treatment.

• Cluster headache management includes both abortive treatment (high-flow oxygen, triptans) and prophylactic treatment. The most common prophylactic medication for cluster headaches is verapamil.
• Among the answer choices:
 -Acetazolamide is used to lower intraocular pressure (acute treatment of glaucoma).
 -Amitriptyline is typically used for migraine or tension headache prophylaxis.
 -Clopidogrel is for antiplatelet stroke prevention.
 -Epinephrine is not used in headache prophylaxis.
 -Verapamil is the classic prophylactic treatment for cluster headaches.

Step 4: Provide the final answer.

The most appropriate prophylaxis for this patient’s condition (cluster headache) is Verapamil.

Final Answer: E. Verapamil

Let’s break down the case step by step.

Step 1. Key Features of the Patient’s Presentation:
• A 64‐year‐old man presents with a headache and nausea.
• The pain is unilateral, localized around his right eye and upper forehead.
• There is one episode of vomiting.
• He also has difficulty seeing out of his right eye with associated tearing.
• On exam the right pupil is minimally reactive to light and the globe feels firm.
• A right‐sided carotid bruit is noted on exam, which, while it may be incidental or related to his vascular disease, does not directly point to the headache syndrome.

Step 2. Differential Diagnosis for Unilateral Headache with Autonomic Symptoms:
The combination of unilateral, periorbital pain with lacrimation (tearing) in an older male is most consistent with a cluster headache. Cluster headaches are known for severe unilateral pain, often around the eye, with autonomic symptoms that can include lacrimation and, sometimes, ptosis or miosis. Although some exam findings (like the firm globe) could suggest increased intraocular pressure seen in conditions such as acute angle-closure glaucoma, the overall clinical picture (including the headache quality, autonomic symptoms, and the patient’s demographics) fits better with cluster headache.

Step 3. Review of the Options for Prophylaxis:
• Acetazolamide – Used mainly in the treatment of glaucoma by reducing intraocular pressure.
• Amitriptyline – A tricyclic antidepressant used for migraine prophylaxis but not the first-line agent for cluster headaches.
• Clopidogrel – An antiplatelet agent used in ischemic disease prophylaxis.
• Epinephrine – Typically used in emergency settings such as anaphylaxis.
• Verapamil – A calcium channel blocker that is considered the first-line prophylactic treatment for cluster headaches.

Step 4. Final Decision:
Given the overall clinical presentation most consistent with cluster headache and the prophylaxis options provided, the best choice for prevention of the patient’s condition is Verapamil.

Final Answer: E. Verapamil

question: A 9-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a fever and a change in her behavior. She presented with similar symptoms 6 weeks ago and was treated for an Escherchia coli infection. She also was treated for a urinary tract infection 10 weeks ago. Her mother says that last night her daughter felt ill, and her condition has been worsening. Her daughter experienced a severe headache and had a stiff neck. This morning she was minimally responsive, vomited several times, and produced a small amount of dark cloudy urine. The patient was born at 39 weeks and met all her developmental milestones. She is currently up to date on her vaccinations and did not have infections during early childhood. Her parents are divorced and her father has noted she does not seem to get sick when he takes care of her. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 60/35 mmHg, pulse is 190/min, respirations are 33/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is started on intravenous fluids, vasopressors, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Which of the following is the most appropriate underlying explanation for this patient's presentation?
reason:
This patient is presenting with repeat sepsis, which is uncommon in a pediatric patient with no significant medical history. This abnormal concentration of infections when the patient is with her mother suggests a diagnosis of intentional contamination.

Factitious disorder by proxy (formerly Munchausen syndrome) occurs when 1 individual creates symptoms in another for attention. Typically, this is a parent feigning or creating symptoms in a child in order to receive the psychiatric gain of attention from healthcare personnel. The patient should be treated and removed from the parents as this is considered child abuse. Factitious disorder by proxy should be suspected in any pediatric patient who has repeat infections that are atypical or not expected epidemiologically. Patients should also be evaluated for organic causes of symptoms such as immunodeficiency syndromes.

Abeln and Love review the evidence regarding the diagnosis of factitious disorder by proxy. They discuss how these disorders have high morbidity and mortality when not accurately recognized. They recommend paying attention to red flags such as abnormal constellations of symptoms.

Incorrect Answers:
Answer A: Gastroenteritis would present with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea; however, it would not present with sepsis routinely. Gastroenteritis does not best explain the most likely underlying cause of this patient's presentation.

Answer B: Immunodeficiency such as severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) would present with lifelong infections from birth that are bacterial, viral, and fungal. Immunodeficiency would not present with repeat infections in a pediatric patient only when they are with one patient.

Answer D: Meningitis would present with headache, altered mental status, and meningeal signs. In the setting of repeat sepsis in a healthy pediatric patient, intentional contamination is more likely. Similarly, an absence of photophobia and no further history/physical exam supporting this diagnosis suggests an alternative diagnosis.

Answer E: Urinary tract infection would present with dysuria rather than repeat episodes of sepsis. Though a urinary tract infection could lead to sepsis, this would be rare and more likely to occur in an immunosuppressed patient, the elderly, or a neonate. UTIs are a common cause of infection and fever in pediatric patients.

Bullet Summary:
Factitious disorder by proxy occurs when 1 individual feigns or creates symptoms in another.
raw_responses:
Let’s analyze the details:

• The patient is a 9‐year-old girl who has had multiple episodes of “infections” in a relatively short time span—a prior E. coli infection treated 6 weeks ago and a urinary tract infection 10 weeks ago. Now she presents with a severely altered mental state, headache, stiff neck, vomiting, and shock. Although these findings could suggest a serious infection like meningitis or sepsis from a UTI, there’s another critical clue.

• Her father notes that when he takes care of her, she “does not seem to get sick.” This disparity between caregivers is a major red flag. In cases of Munchausen syndrome by proxy (also known as factitious disorder imposed on another), a caregiver deliberately produces or fabricates symptoms in a child in order to gain attention or other benefits from the medical system.

• The diverse and atypical presentation, which includes signs of meningitis as well as urinary abnormalities (like the dark, cloudy urine), coupled with the fact that her illnesses occur only when she is under one caregiver’s supervision, strongly suggests that someone might be intentionally contaminating her samples or inducing symptoms.

• Let’s compare the provided options:
 A. Gastroenteritis – Doesn’t fit the neurological signs.
 B. Immunodeficiency – Less likely given her normal development and the observation that she is well under her father’s care.
 C. Intentional contamination – Fits with the caregiver discrepancy and the pattern of recurrences.
 D. Meningitis – While she does have meningitic signs, this does not account for the pattern of repeated illnesses and the caregiver discrepancy.
 E. Urinary tract infection – Again, does not explain the overall clinical picture and the inconsistent occurrence with different caregivers.

The most appropriate explanation is that the caregiver (implied to be the one present when the child is sick) is intentionally contaminating or inducing the symptoms.

Final answer: C. Intentional contamination

Step 1: Review the patient’s details.  
• A 9‐year-old girl presents with fever, behavior changes, headache, stiff neck, vomiting, and dark cloudy urine.  
• She had similar symptoms 6 weeks ago (treated for an E. coli infection) and a UTI 10 weeks ago.  
• Her father notes that she does not seem to get sick when she’s in his care.  
• The child is developmentally normal and up to date on vaccinations.

Step 2: Analyze the options against her presentation.  
A. Gastroenteritis – This would mainly cause vomiting and diarrhea, not stiff neck or meningitic signs.  
B. Immunodeficiency – Though recurrent infections can suggest this, the history of being healthy with her father and her current vaccination history argue against a primary immunodeficiency.  
C. Intentional contamination – The fact that she presents with recurrent infections only in one care setting (implied to be under her mother’s care) raises concern for caregiver-induced illness (factitious disorder imposed on another). The repeated E. coli UTIs and now a severe presentation (shock, meningitic signs) in a clinically well, vaccinated child are worrisome.  
D. Meningitis – While she has features (headache, stiff neck) that might be seen in meningitis, this does not explain the recurring nature of the infections or the detail provided by her father’s observation.  
E. Urinary tract infection – Recurrence of a UTI is noted, but it would be unusual for a simple UTI to repeatedly occur in a child who appears well in one care setting and then progress to a shock state with meningitic signs.

Step 3: Synthesize the findings.  
The critical clue is that the child’s illnesses occur only when she is with a particular caregiver. This pattern is highly concerning for intentional contamination or symptom fabrication by the caregiver—a presentation seen in factitious disorder imposed on another (formerly known as Munchausen syndrome by proxy).

Final Answer: C. Intentional contamination

Step 1: Identify key details from the stem.
• The patient is a 9‐year‐old girl with fever, behavioral changes, headache, stiff neck, vomiting, and dark, cloudy urine.
• She has had similar episodes in the recent past (6 weeks ago with an E. coli infection and 10 weeks ago with a UTI).
• Her vital signs indicate shock (blood pressure 60/35 mmHg, pulse 190/min).
• Notably, her father mentions that “she does not seem to get sick when he takes care of her,” raising a red flag regarding differences in care between parents.

Step 2: Consider and eliminate the options.
A. Gastroenteritis – This doesn’t explain the recurrent UTIs, shock, and meningitic signs.
B. Immunodeficiency – The patient’s normal developmental history, routine childhood experiences without recurrent severe infections, and being up to date with vaccinations argue against a primary immunodeficiency.
C. Intentional contamination – The recurrent infections, particularly UTIs and now signs that could represent meningitis or sepsis, combined with the observation that the patient well when with her father, raise concern for possible factitious disorder imposed by a caregiver. This is classically seen as Munchausen syndrome by proxy, where the caregiver intentionally contaminates samples or incites illness.
D. Meningitis – Although the patient has features (headache, stiff neck, altered mental status) suggestive of meningitis, this option identifies a diagnosis rather than an underlying explanation for the recurrent and suspicious nature of her infections.
E. Urinary tract infection – While the child has had UTIs, this option accounts for only part of her presentation and does not explain the recurrent episodes, the additional systemic symptoms, or the discrepancy in her illness severity under different parental care.

Step 3: Synthesize the findings.
The history of recurrent infections (particularly UTIs), the critical state with signs of possible meningitis or septic shock, and the fact that the girl appears well when cared for by her father strongly support the possibility of intentional contamination or induced illness by the caregiver.

Final Answer: C. Intentional contamination.

question: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department after fainting. He was outside tending to his lawn for several hours in the heat, when he stood up suddenly from pulling weeds and fainted. He denies any preceding symptoms and returned to baseline within 1 minute. The patient is not aware of any medical problems and just started seeing a primary care physician last week. He recently used a friend's prescription for ondansetron for nausea. His temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 142/88 mmHg, pulse is 107/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam reveals intact cranial nerves, normal strength and sensation, and a stable gait. His abdomen is soft and nontender. An ECG is performed as seen in Figure A. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on this patient’s ECG?
reason:
This patient is presenting after syncope, likely secondary to dehydration and orthostatic hypotension given his outdoor gardening in the heat and symptoms when standing up rapidly. The patient’s ECG reveals deep, pathologic Q waves, which in this case are an incidental finding indicative of a previous myocardial infarction or a previous ischemic event.

The Q wave is a negative deflection just prior to the R wave. Q waves are a normal finding when they are small and are seen on most ECGs. However, pathologic Q waves are indicative of myocardial ischemia. Pathologic Q waves are generally diagnosed when they are >2 mm deep, >1 mm wide, >25% of the QRS complex height, or are seen in leads V1-V3. The interpretation of Q waves depends on other findings on ECG and the patient's symptoms. Deep Q waves in the setting of ST elevation indicate an acute myocardial infarction. On the other hand, pathologic Q waves found incidentally indicate a previous myocardial infarction or previous ischemic event.

Rovai et al. review Q waves. They discuss how Q waves can be used to predict the location and size of a myocardial infarction as correlated with MRI. They recommend testing such as cardiac MRI to assess for previous infarction in the appropriate patient population.

Figure/Illustration A is an ECG demonstrating pathologic Q waves (red arrows). Note the deep and wide Q waves; this raises concern for a past ischemic event.

Incorrect Answers:
Answer A: Acute myocardial infarctions would present with ST elevation in a vascular distribution on ECG with possible reciprocal depressions. While T wave inversions may be indicative of new or acute ischemia, deep pathologic Q waves without ST elevation are indicative of previous infarction.

Answer B: Hypokalemia would cause U waves on ECG, which appear as a small, "second T wave" after the initial T wave. Note they are not U-shaped despite their name. Management is centered on repletion of potassium and often magnesium as well.

Answer C: Intermittent torsades de pointes can cause syncope and should be suspected in a patient with syncope in the setting of a prolonged QT interval. This patient’s QT interval is not particularly prolonged, and his syncope seems to be secondary to orthostatic hypotension. Management is centered on cessation of QT-prolonging medications and magnesium administration. Note that while ondansetron does prolong the QT interval, it is unlikely to cause torsades given the patient took it a week ago.

Answer E: Pulmonary emboli would present on ECG with sinus tachycardia in addition to pleuritic chest pain and hypoxia. Note that the ECG is a nonspecific test for pulmonary emboli, and CT angiography is the preferred confirmatory test for this condition. Syncope is a possible presentation of larger pulmonary emboli (though the patient would also be hemodynamically unstable).

Bullet Summary:
Pathologic Q waves are indicative of a previous myocardial infarction.
raw_responses:
Step 1: Analyze the patient’s presentation and history. The patient is an elderly man who experienced a syncopal episode after standing up in a hot environment. Notably, he recently took ondansetron, a medication known to potentially prolong the QT interval on the ECG.

Step 2: Consider the ECG in context of the clinical scenario. While the full details of Figure A are not provided, the available answer choices prompt us to consider various ECG abnormalities. Given the patient’s recent use of ondansetron and the possibility of a medication-induced effect, the most likely abnormality on the ECG would be a prolonged QT interval or episodes of a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, such as torsades de pointes. Ondansetron is well known for its association with QT prolongation, which can lead to torsades de pointes, a type of ventricular tachycardia.

Step 3: Evaluate and eliminate other options:
• Option A (Acute myocardial infarction): The patient does not exhibit typical ischemic symptoms, and his presentation is more consistent with a medication-induced arrhythmia.
• Option B (Hypokalemia): Although hypokalemia can cause ECG changes and might lead to arrhythmias, there is no clinical or laboratory evidence pointing to low potassium in this case.
• Option D (Previous myocardial ischemia): There is no history or physical exam finding supporting prior ischemia.
• Option E (Pulmonary embolism): The patient’s presentation and current exam do not support this diagnosis, and pulmonary embolism typically produces different ECG findings (e.g., S1Q3T3 pattern).

Step 4: Provide the final answer based on the analysis. Given that ondansetron is known to prolong the QT interval and predispose to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, the most likely diagnosis based on the patient’s ECG is:

Final Answer: C. Intermittent torsades des pointes

He also recently used ondansetron, a medication known to prolong the QT interval on an ECG, which can precipitate arrhythmias. His exam is normal, and his vitals do not suggest an acute myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, or electrolyte imbalance on first look.

Step 2: Consider the ECG findings. Although the actual ECG image (Figure A) isn’t provided in the text, the clinical course (syncope with recent ondansetron use) raises concerns for a drug-induced arrhythmia, particularly torsades de pointes, which is associated with a prolonged QT interval. Among the answer choices:
 • A. Acute myocardial infarction – Unlikely, as his symptoms are more consistent with a benign syncopal episode, and the ECG would show ST changes in MI.
 • B. Hypokalemia – While hypokalemia can prolong the QT interval, there is no clear evidence of electrolyte abnormality.
 • C. Intermittent torsades des pointes – This fits well with his ondansetron use and syncope, with the ECG likely reflecting prolonged QT or episodes of torsades.
 • D. Previous myocardial ischemia – There’s no history or ECG indication that points toward an old infarct.
 • E. Pulmonary embolism – The clinical context and ECG would typically show a pattern in the right ventricle or tachycardia, not what is suggested by this case.

Step 3: Final Answer  
The best answer is: C. Intermittent torsades des pointes.

• Hypokalemia (Option B) can cause ECG changes but is unsupported by his history.

• Pulmonary embolism (Option E) is less consistent with his overall presentation.

Final Answer: C. Intermittent torsades des pointes

question: A 34-year-old man is brought to a rural emergency department by ambulance after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Paramedics report that the patient was driving the car and crashed into a tree at roughly 25 miles per hour. There were no passengers and he was awake but disoriented at the scene. His temperature is 97.9°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 131/88 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, and respirations are 14/min. He is speaking but is confused, opens his eyes to voice commands, and follows simple commands. He has multiple lacerations on his face and arms and smells of alcohol and marijuana. His cardiac exam is normal and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. He has bruising over his abdomen without any tenderness to palpation, distension, or rigidity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.E: Focused abdominal sonography for trauma exam

reason:
This patient presents following a motor vehicle accident with a tender abdomen and stable vital signs. Given his stability, the most appropriate next step is an abdominal and chest CT.

In blunt abdominal trauma, the next step in management depends upon whether the patient is hemodynamically stable. With a normal blood pressure and pulse within the normal range, patients can undergo imaging to evaluate for injury to the abdominal organs with the most appropriate study being an abdominal CT with contrast. This study can accurately localize bleeding and aid in operative planning. A bedside ultrasound known as the FAST exam is often performed in unstable patients. Unstable patients, patients with abdominal tenderness, and patients with a severe mechanism of trauma may have a bedside FAST exam performed. If the free fluid is localized, the patient can be transferred directly to the operating room. Note that in many hospitals, the FAST exam is done simultaneously with the primary and secondary survey; however, if asked to choose which exam to perform on a trauma patient who is stable with no signs of a surgical abdomen, a CT scan should be performed to more accurately assess the patient's injuries and assess for injuries that may be missed by a FAST exam.

Feliciano reviewed the evidence surrounding the current diagnosis and management of abdominal trauma. He discusses how contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis is an important method for evaluating the etiology of intra-abdominal bleeding. He recommends considering damage control methods in the polytrauma patient.

Answer B: Chest radiography has limited utility in the setting of blunt abdominal trauma; however, a portable anterior-posterior film is often taken in trauma, in particular, when the patient is intoxicated. Thus it would be both difficult to obtain and less useful when compared to a CT scan given his traumatic injuries. Findings on chest radiograph could suggest abdominal injury, such as lower rib fractures or free air under the diaphragm, which would suggest intestinal perforation.

Answer C: Diagnostic laparoscopy may play a role in evaluating for injury in penetrating traumas such as gunshot wounds or stabbing wounds but would not be indicated as the most appropriate initial step in management in a stable patient. Unstable patients, surgical abdomens, and positive FAST exams or CT scans warrant transfer to the operating room.

Answer D: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is a historical test to assess for intra-abdominal injury that was typically used with ambiguous FAST exams or patients where it was unclear whether there was abdominal bleeding; however, it has almost entirely been supplanted by the FAST exam.

Bullet Summary:
In a patient who has experienced blunt abdominal trauma the most appropriate initial step in a stable patient is an abdominal CT scan.

question: A 17-year-old boy presents to his primary care physician with a chief concern of "bad" skin that has not improved despite home remedies. The patient has had lesions on his face that have persisted since he was 13 years of age. He has a diet high in refined carbohydrates and has gained 20 pounds since starting high school. Physical exam is notable for the findings in Figure A. The patient is started on benzoyl peroxide and topical retinoids. He returns 1 month later stating that his symptoms are roughly the same. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.A: Continue current therapy for 1 more month

reason:
This patient is presenting with persistent acne vulgaris that is refractory to topical benzoyl peroxide and retinoids. The next step in management is topical antibiotics.

Acne vulgaris is caused by blockage or outlet obstruction of the pilosebaceous unit. It presents with erythema, pustules, and comedones typically in young men going through puberty. Risk factors include stress, excessive sweating, greasy skin care products, and steroid use. The management of acne vulgaris, in order, is to start with topical benzoyl peroxide and topical retinoids, topical antibiotics, oral antibiotics, and isoretinoin. It is important to try a therapy for a proper duration before switching to a more invasive therapy.

Eichenfield et al. review the evidence regarding the treatment of patients with acne vulgaris. They discuss how this disease can be treated with benzoyl peroxide. They recommend using antibiotics or isotretinoin for refractory cases.

Figure/Illustration A is a clinical photograph demonstrating diffuse comedones over the forehead (red circle). These findings are classically seen in patients with acne vulgaris.

Incorrect Answers:
Answer A: Continuing current therapy for 1 more month is unnecessary as this patient's symptoms have not improved at all with 1 month of therapy. Continuing current therapy would be appropriate if the patient had only tried therapy for a few days.

Answer B: Dietary interventions have not been shown to improve outcomes in acne vulgaris. Stopping illicit substances such as performance enhancing steroids can be effective in reducing acne symptoms but there is no evidence this patient has been using steroids.

Answer C: Isoretinoin is the last-line therapy for acne vulgaris. It should not be given to pregnant women as it is teratogenic. Women taking isoretinoin should be on reliable birth control. Topical and oral antibiotics should be used first.

Answer D: Oral antibiotics would be indicated after topical antibiotics fail. Topical antibiotics should be tried first as these do not have systemic side effects.

Bullet Summary:
The management of acne vulgaris is to start with topical benzoyl peroxide and topical retinoids, followed by topical antibiotics, oral antibiotics, and isoretinoin in increasing order of severity.

question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath that he experienced while barbecuing. The pain is over his chest and in his left arm. The patient has a medical history of obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. His current medications include insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. An ECG is performed and is seen in Figure A. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. The patient is appropriately managed and is admitted to the step-down unit. 2 days later, he complains of chest pain. A repeat ECG is performed and is seen in Figure B. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's underlying condition?
reason:
This patient is presenting with chest pain several days after sustaining a myocardial infarction and has an ECG suggestive of pericarditis. This presentation is consistent with Dressler syndrome and the most appropriate initial step in management is aspirin.

Dressler syndrome is pericarditis that can occur after a myocardial infarction (MI). It most commonly occurs weeks to months after the MI, but can also occur within 1 week from an MI in rare cases. It is believed to result from an autoimmune reaction that occurs after damage to the heart (surgery and MI). It presents with chest pain, fever, pleuritic pain, and a pericardial friction rub. ECG demonstrates diffuse ST elevation with PR depression consistent with pericarditis. The most appropriate initial step in the management of this condition is symptomatic management with aspirin.

Leib et al. review the evidence regarding the diagnosis and treatment of Dressler syndrome. They discuss how this condition is secondary pericarditis with or without pericardial effusion resulting from injury to the heart or pericardium. They recommend considering this syndrome in all patients with chest pain after a myocardial infarction.

Figure/Illustration A demonstrates an ECG with ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF (blue circles) suggesting a diagnosis of right-sided MI.

Figure/Illustration B demonstrates an ECG with diffuse ST elevation and PR depression (blue circles) suggesting a diagnosis of pericarditis.

Incorrect Answers:
Answers 1 & 5: Angiography and stenting would be appropriate management if this patient were experiencing a repeat MI. The diffuse ST elevation and PR depression seen several days after his myocardial infarction are more indicative of pericarditis rather than a repeat MI. In addition, the chest pain the patient is experiencing can also occur in pericarditis and obfuscates the diagnosis of repeat MI.

Answers 3 & 4: Ibuprofen, other NSAIDs, and corticosteroids such as prednisone are not first-line therapy in post-MI pericarditis as they can hinder the healing and remodeling process of the myocardium. Current guidelines dictate that they may be used in cases that are refractory to initial therapy.

Bullet Summary:
Dressler syndrome (post-MI pericarditis) presents with chest pain, pericardial friction rub, fever, and diffuse ST elevation with PR depression on ECG, and should be treated initially with aspirin.
raw_responses:
Step 1: Review the Patient’s History and Presentation
• The patient initially presented with chest pain and shortness of breath, leading to a diagnosis of myocardial infarction (MI) (details of the initial ECG likely supported this).
• Two days later, he experiences renewed chest pain. Given his recent MI, this raises concern for a complication related to the infarction.

Step 2: Consider Post‐MI Complications
• One known complication that can present within the first few days after an MI is acute pericarditis (sometimes called post-infarction pericarditis).
• This condition typically presents with chest pain and can show ECG changes different from the initial infarction pattern.

Step 3: Evaluate the Treatment Options
A. Angiography – Typically considered when there’s suspicion for recurrent ischemia or a mechanical complication, but it’s not the mainstay for management of post-MI pericarditis.
B. Aspirin – High-dose aspirin is the treatment of choice for post-MI pericarditis. It has anti-inflammatory properties and is preferred over other NSAIDs in the post-MI setting to avoid interference with healing.
C. Ibuprofen – Although it is an NSAID with anti-inflammatory effects, ibuprofen is usually avoided post-MI because it can impair myocardial healing.
D. Prednisone – Corticosteroids are generally avoided in post-MI pericarditis due to their potential to worsen hemorrhage, interfere with scar formation, and increase the risk of complications.
E. Stenting – This would be indicated for ongoing coronary occlusion, but in this setting, there’s no direct evidence of re-occlusion requiring emergent intervention.

Step 4: Final Decision
Based on the given options and the patient’s presentation along with the typical post-MI complication (pericarditis) that arises within a few days after the infarct, the best next step in management is to treat with high-dose aspirin.

Final Answer: B. Aspirin

Step 1: Gather the clinical data. The patient, a 62‐year‐old man with coronary risk factors, initially presented with a myocardial infarction. Two days into his hospital course he develops new chest pain with a repeat ECG (Figure B) that is different from his initial ECG (Figure A).

Step 2: Recognize the likely diagnosis. In the setting of a recent MI, the development of chest pain a couple of days later with ECG changes is most consistent with acute pericarditis (post–MI pericarditis) rather than re-infarction or stent thrombosis. This acute pericarditis occurs due to the inflammatory response to myocardial necrosis, and it can present with chest pain that may be positional and is often associated with diffuse or concave upward ST elevations on ECG.

Step 3: Evaluate the management options. For post–MI pericarditis, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are used in management; however, while ibuprofen (a typical NSAID) might be considered for idiopathic pericarditis, it is generally avoided in the early post–MI period because it can impair myocardial healing. Instead, high-dose aspirin is preferred because it provides anti-inflammatory effects while being cardioprotective in the post-MI setting. Angiography and stenting would be indicated for recurrent ischemia or re-infarction, but the clinical and ECG findings here are more consistent with an inflammatory process. Prednisone is reserved for patients who do not respond to aspirin or have contraindications to NSAIDs.

Step 4: Conclusion. Among the options provided, high-dose Aspirin is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s post–MI pericarditis.

Final answer: B. Aspirin

Step 2: Consider the complication. The timing (within days of the MI) and the recurrence of chest pain suggest post–MI pericarditis (also known as early postinfarction pericarditis) rather than Dressler syndrome, which typically occurs weeks later.

Step 3: Determine proper treatment for post–MI pericarditis. In the setting of acute pericarditis after MI, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are typically used. However, most NSAIDs (eg, ibuprofen) are avoided because they can interfere with myocardial scar formation. High-dose aspirin is preferred because, besides its anti-inflammatory properties, it also preserves the beneficial antiplatelet effect necessary in the post-MI setting. Corticosteroids (eg, prednisone) are generally reserved for cases where high-dose aspirin is contraindicated or poorly tolerated due to potential adverse effects on healing.

Step 4: Eliminate incorrect options.
• Angiography and stenting are interventions typically used for acute coronary syndromes and revascularization, not for post–MI pericarditis.
• Ibuprofen is contraindicated due to its negative effects on myocardial healing post-MI.
• Prednisone is not first-line as initial management for post–MI pericarditis.

Step 5: Final answer.
The best next step in management for this patient’s underlying condition is high-dose aspirin.

Final Answer: Aspirin

question: A 4-week-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for an initial evaluation. His parents are concerned that he is not feeding well and has lost weight over the last 2 weeks. He was born at home via spontaneous vaginal delivery at 37 weeks of gestation to a G1P1 mother. His mother did not receive prenatal care. His blood pressure is 70/44 mmHg, pulse is 151/min, and respirations are 41/min. His weight is 3 kg (4th percentile) compared with 3.5 kg at birth (45th percentile). On physical exam, he is jaundiced with an enlarged liver and spleen. He does not appear to respond to visual stimuli, and further examination reveals bilateral clouding of the lens. Which of the following interventions could have avoided this patient's symptoms?
answer: Changing to a soy based formula

options.A: Avoiding fruit juice and sweetened foods
options.B: Changing to a soy based formula
options.D: Removing phenylalanine from maternal diet during pregnancy

reason:
This patient who presents with failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, and bilateral cataracts most likely has classic galactosemia. Patients with this disorder should avoid lactose-containing products by changing to a soy-based formula.

Classic galactosemia is an autosomal recessive defect in galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase. This enzyme is involved in the conversion of galactose to glucose, and a deficiency of this enzyme results in the accumulation of galactose 1-phosphate in the liver, kidney, and brain. This metabolite acts as a phosphate sink, meaning that it traps all free phosphate in the cytosol and inhibits the formation of other phosphate-dependent metabolites such as adenosine triphosphate. This results in failure to thrive, vomiting, lethargy, and hepatosplenomegaly after ingestion of galactose-containing products such as milk. Patients will also develop bilateral cataracts if the deficit is not detected in the first few weeks after birth. Avoiding galactose by changing to a soy-based formula will avoid the complications of this disorder.

Turck discusses using soy protein for infant feeding. The author notes that there are safety concerns with regards to the high phyto-estrogenic isoflavone content of these formulas. The author recommends that despite these safety concerns, these formulas should still be used in patients with classic galactosemia.

Incorrect Answers:
Answer A: Avoiding fruit juice and sweetened foods would be effective in the treatment of hereditary fructose intolerance. This disease presents similarly to classic galactosemia, but cataracts would not be seen in patients with this disease.

Answer C: Providing imiglucerase enzyme replacement would be effective in the treatment of patients with Gaucher disease, which can also present with failure to thrive. However, associated findings in this disease would be anemia and avascular necrosis of the bones.

Answer D: Removing phenylalanine from the maternal diet during pregnancy would be effective in the treatment of patients with phenylketonuria, which can also present with failure to thrive. However, these patients classically present with a "musty smell" and eczema.

Answer E: Vitamin B6 supplementation may be effective in mitigating the negative symptoms of homocystinuria. This disease may also present with cataracts or lens dislocations. Associated findings in this disorder would be marfanoid appearance and arachnodactyly.

Bullet Summary:
Patients with classic galactosemia should not be breastfed and should receive a galactose-free and lactose-free diet such as soy-based formulas.
raw_responses:
Step 1: Review the patient's presentation. The 4‐week-old boy has poor feeding, weight loss, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and bilateral lens clouding. These findings are classic for galactosemia, an inborn error of galactose metabolism that usually presents soon after initiating milk feeds, as it involves the accumulation of toxic metabolites of galactose (e.g., galactitol).

Step 2: Evaluate the options.
• Option A (Avoiding fruit juice and sweetened foods) is not relevant because the problem is with galactose from milk products, not fructose.
• Option B (Changing to a soy based formula) would remove lactose (and therefore galactose) from the infant's diet, preventing the accumulation of toxic metabolites.
• Option C (Providing imiglucerase enzyme replacement) is used for Gaucher disease, not for galactosemia.
• Option D (Removing phenylalanine from maternal diet during pregnancy) is relevant to phenylketonuria, not galactosemia.
• Option E (Vitamin B6 supplementation) is used for certain metabolic conditions like pyridoxine-dependent seizures, not galactosemia.

Step 3: By eliminating the irrelevant options and based on the fact that the patient’s symptoms are consistent with galactosemia, the best intervention to avoid these symptoms would have been to eliminate dietary galactose by switching to a soy-based formula.

Final Answer: B

• These findings are strongly suggestive of classic galactosemia, which results from an inability to metabolize galactose due to a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase. Accumulation of toxic substances such as galactitol leads to liver damage and cataracts.

Step 2: Review and eliminate the answer choices.
A. Avoiding fruit juice and sweetened foods – These dietary modifications are unrelated to galactosemia.
B. Changing to a soy based formula – Soy-based formulas do not contain lactose (and thus galactose), and switching would prevent the toxic accumulation of galactose metabolites.
C. Providing imiglucerase enzyme replacement – This treatment is used for Gaucher disease, not galactosemia.
D. Removing phenylalanine from maternal diet during pregnancy – This intervention is relevant to phenylketonuria, which presents differently.
E. Vitamin B6 supplementation – This is used for pyridoxine-dependent seizures, not galactosemia.

The patient’s symptoms are consistent with classic galactosemia, which is prevented by eliminating galactose from the diet. Using a soy-based formula instead of a lactose-containing formula would have avoided exposure to galactose.

question: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family. They found her somnolent next to her computer with an empty pill bottle around 3 hours ago. The family cannot recall the types of pill bottles that they found and did not bring them to the ED. The patient's medical history is notable for anxiety, obesity, hypertension, and polycystic ovarian syndrome. She is currently not on any medications. She was given an exercise program but she has not been compliant with these exercises. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, respirations are 11/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam is within normal limits. The patient begins communicating with the physician and states that she did take acetaminophen but it was only a few pills. Her parents are certain the bottle was new. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
reason:
This patient is presenting with acute acetaminophen intoxication. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer the antidote N-acetyl cysteine (NAC).

In a toxicology case where the ingestion is unknown, the most appropriate initial step in management is to begin treatment empirically with IV fluids, charcoal, NAC, naloxone, and glucose if needed. These agents are effective against the most common causes of intoxication. In cases where there is known acetaminophen ingestion, the most important treatment is prompt administration of NAC. This medication works by increasing the hepatic production of glutathione, which detoxifies the toxic metabolite of acetaminophen N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI). NAC is a safe, cheap, and effective treatment that could be life-saving if administered in a timely fashion. In massive overdoses, it is appropriate to start treatment empirically as it can be discontinued later. Otherwise, a 4 hour acetaminophen level should be collected and the level should be plotted on the Rumack Matthew nomogram to determine treatment. In chronic acetaminophen toxicity, the acute serum level play no role in guiding treatment.

Chiew et al. performed a meta-analysis regarding the treatment of acetaminophen overdose. They found that the administration of charcoal immediately after ingestion can decrease the rate of absorption of acetaminophen. They recommend early administration of N-acetyl cysteine in order to decrease the hepatotoxicity of this substance.

Incorrect Answers:
Answer A: Blood acetaminophen levels should be ordered, but it is much less dire to confirm the diagnosis than it is to begin treatment given the high fatality rate with untreated acetaminophen overdose. Testing for all common intoxication should proceed while treatment is being administered. In this case, the concern for consumption of an entire bottle of acetaminophen would make it reasonable to treat first.

Answer B: Charcoal is an appropriate intervention if it is given in a timely manner; however, this patient consumed acetaminophen over 2 hours ago. In general, if the patient's airway is secure, it does no harm and could offer some benefit by decreasing the absorption of the substance of interest.

Answer C: IV fluid administration is the most appropriate initial step in the management of trauma when there is suspected bleeding and vitals are unstable (hypotension and tachycardia). Fluids are not urgently needed in this toxicity case with a patient who has stable vitals.

Answer E: Syrup of ipecac induces emesis in patients and was previously used in an attempt to have the patient vomit the toxic substance. This is no longer a preferred method of managing toxicities as patients can aspirate the vomitus or the toxic substance can induce more tissue damage during vomiting. In general, syrup of ipecac is the wrong answer choice for all toxicity cases.

Bullet Summary:
Acetaminophen toxicity should be treated immediately with N-acetyl cysteine followed by further diagnostic workup including serum acetaminophen levels.
raw_responses:
Step 1: Recognize that even though the patient was found next to an empty pill bottle suggesting a possible overdose, her history and account indicate that she only ingested a few acetaminophen pills. The fact that the bottle was new supports her account, lowering the likelihood of a massive overdose.

Step 2: In suspected acetaminophen overdose, determining the serum acetaminophen level is critical. This level is best interpreted in the context of the Rumack-Matthew nomogram (typically at 4 hours or later post-ingestion). Although she presented 3 hours post-ingestion, obtaining a level now (or repeating it at the appropriate time) is necessary to decide whether treatment with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is indicated.

Step 3: Reviewing the options:
• Blood acetaminophen levels (Option A) is the appropriate next step to evaluate for potential toxicity.
• Activated charcoal (Option B) is most effective if given within 1 hour of ingestion.
• Lactated Ringer bolus (Option C) is appropriate for volume resuscitation, which is not indicated here.
• N-acetylcysteine (Option D) is administered if the acetaminophen level is in the toxic range, but it is premature without lab confirmation.
• Syrup of ipecac (Option E) is not recommended in modern overdose management.

Final Answer: A. Blood acetaminophen levels

Step 1: Recognize that when there is a concern for acetaminophen overdose, time is critical. Although the patient states she only ingested a few pills, her family’s report that the pill bottle was new raises concern that she may have taken the entire bottle. When there is even a possibility of a toxic ingestion, management should be directed toward rapid antidotal treatment.

Step 2: In acetaminophen overdose the antidote is N‑acetylcysteine (NAC), and it is most effective when started early (ideally within 8 hours). While serum acetaminophen levels are used (via the Rumack-Matthew nomogram) to guide further management, these levels are only reliably measured at least 4 hours post‑ingestion. Since the patient presents 3 hours after ingestion, a level drawn now would be premature and could be falsely reassuring. Activated charcoal is most useful within 1–2 hours after ingestion (and can be considered up to 4 hours in some settings), but given the uncertain history and potential for significant overdose, it would not replace the need for timely antidote.

Step 3: Therefore, given the uncertainty of the ingestion amount but the high suspicion for a significant acetaminophen overdose, the most appropriate next step is to initiate treatment with N‑acetylcysteine right away.

Final Answer: D. N‑acetylcysteine

The patient was found with an empty pill bottle, and her parents note that the bottle was new, which raises concern for the possibility of an overdose despite her own statement that she only ingested a few acetaminophen pills. The timeline is approximately 3 hours post-ingestion. Although she is hemodynamically stable and awake, there is still ambiguity surrounding the actual amount ingested.

Step 2: Consider the Options
• Option A: Blood acetaminophen levels – In cases of suspected acetaminophen overdose, obtaining a serum acetaminophen level is essential to guide further treatment decisions using the Rumack-Matthew nomogram.
• Option B: Activated charcoal – Most effective if given within 1–2 hours of ingestion. At 3 hours post-ingestion, its efficacy is reduced.
• Option C: Lactated Ringer bolus – This is used in the management of volume depletion or shock, neither of which the patient exhibits.
• Option D: N-acetylcysteine – This antidote is indicated for acetaminophen toxicity, but its administration should ideally be based on serum levels unless the history clearly supports a large overdose.
• Option E: Syrup of ipecac – This is no longer recommended for poisoning as it is ineffective and potentially harmful.

Step 3: Determine the Best Next Step
Given the uncertainty regarding the amount ingested and the critical time window in which acetaminophen toxicity can be managed, the most appropriate next step is to obtain blood acetaminophen levels. This measurement will help determine if the patient is at risk for hepatotoxicity and whether N-acetylcysteine should be administered.

Final Answer: A. Blood acetaminophen levels

question: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. She was hiking when she suddenly felt unable to breathe and had to take slow deep breaths to improve her symptoms. The patient is a Swedish foreign exchange student and does not speak any English. Her medical history and current medications are unknown. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Physical exam is notable for poor air movement bilaterally and tachycardia. The patient is started on treatment. Which of the following parameters including forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), forced vital capacity (FVC), and diffusing capacity of carbon monoxide (DLCO) most appropriately describes this patient's underlying pathology?
reason:
This patient who presents with dyspnea and poor air movement bilaterally most likely has an acute asthma exacerbation. DLCO is the one parameter that is normal in these episodes.

Asthma is an obstructive lung disease that results in intermittent episodes of respiratory compromise. Asthma presents with shortness of breath typically secondary to an allergen/antigen or with exposure to exercise or cold air that causes bronchospasm. Pulmonary function testing will typically reveal a decreased FEV1, a decreased FVC, and a decreased FEV1/FVC in both asthma and emphysema. The DLCO will be normal in asthma in contrast to emphysema where the DLCO is decreased. Patients should be treated with inhaled beta-adrenergic agonists and corticosteroids for acute exacerbations.

Peng et al. review the evidence regarding patients who have COPD versus asthma. They discuss how patients with COPD have reduced DLCO. They recommend measuring parameters to distinguish between these entities.

Incorrect Answers:
Answer A: Decreased airway tone does not describe asthma. Rather, hyperreactive airways with increased tone describes an asthma attack. Decreased airway tone may be seen in patients with connective tissue diseases such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Answers 2-4: Increased FEV1, FEV1/FVC, and FVC do not describe asthma. All of these laboratory values are decreased in asthma and emphysema. Increased respiratory performance can be seen in patients who are athletes or training for marathons.

Bullet Summary:
Both asthma and emphysema present with a decreased FEV1, FVC, and FEV1/FVC; however, asthma has a normal DLCO while COPD has a reduced DLCO.
raw_responses:
Step 1: The clinical picture is consistent with an obstructive airway process such as asthma. Asthma typically presents with sudden onset shortness of breath, wheezing, tachycardia, and poor air movement on exam.

Step 2: In asthma, pulmonary function tests typically show a decreased FEV1 with a normal or slightly reduced FVC, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. The diffusing capacity of carbon monoxide (DLCO) remains normal because the alveolar-capillary membrane is not primarily affected.

Step 3: Reviewing the options:
• A. Decreased airway tone – Incorrect; asthma involves bronchoconstriction (increased airway tone), not a decrease.
• B. Increased FEV1 – Incorrect; FEV1 is decreased in asthma.
• C. Increased FEV1/FVC – Incorrect; asthma produces a reduced ratio due to a drop in FEV1.
• D. Increased FVC – Incorrect; FVC is typically normal or only slightly decreased.
• E. Normal DLCO – Correct; DLCO remains normal in asthma.

Final Answer: E. Normal DLCO

Step 1: The patient is a young woman presenting with shortness of breath after exercise (hiking), tachycardia, and low oxygen saturation with poor air movement on exam. This presentation is consistent with an obstructive airway pathology such as asthma, particularly exercise-induced bronchospasm.

Step 2: In asthma, the typical pulmonary function test (PFT) pattern is an obstructive defect where the forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) is decreased and the forced vital capacity (FVC) may be normal or slightly decreased, leading to a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio. However, the diffusing capacity of carbon monoxide (DLCO) is typically normal (or sometimes slightly increased) because the alveolar-capillary membrane is not affected.

Step 3: Reviewing the options:
• Option A ("Decreased airway tone") is inconsistent with asthma, which involves bronchoconstriction (increased tone).
• Option B ("Increased FEV1") is not seen in obstructive lung disease.
• Option C ("Increased FEV1/FVC") would be more characteristic of a restrictive pattern, not asthma.
• Option D ("Increased FVC") does not fit with the obstructive profile.
• Option E ("Normal DLCO") is the parameter that best fits the underlying pathology of asthma.

Final Answer: E (Normal DLCO)

Step 1 – Assess the clinical scenario:
• A 22-year-old woman suddenly developed shortness of breath while hiking.
• Vital signs reveal tachycardia (120/min) and hypoxia (90% on room air).
• The exam shows poor air movement bilaterally.
• These findings are most consistent with an acute asthma exacerbation (an obstructive airway pathology).

Step 2 – Analyze characteristic pulmonary function test (PFT) findings in asthma:
• In asthma (an obstructive disorder), the FEV1 is decreased (due to airway narrowing) while the FVC is usually normal or only slightly decreased.
• This leads to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio.
• Importantly, the diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) in asthma is typically normal because the alveolar-capillary membrane is not affected.

Step 3 – Evaluate the options:
A. Decreased airway tone – Incorrect; asthma is characterized by bronchoconstriction (increased airway tone).
B. Increased FEV1 – Incorrect; FEV1 is reduced during an acute asthma exacerbation.
C. Increased FEV1/FVC – Incorrect; the ratio is decreased in obstructive disease.
D. Increased FVC – Incorrect; FVC is usually normal, not increased.
E. Normal DLCO – Correct; in asthma the DLCO remains normal since alveolar architecture is preserved.

Final Answer: E. Normal DLCO

question: A 56-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with muscle weakness. Her symptoms have progressively worsened over the course of 2 weeks and are most significant in her lower extremities. She also notices increased urinary frequency. Approximately 1 month ago, she was diagnosed with calcium phosphate nephrolithiasis. Medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed approximately 10 years ago and treated with methotrexate as well as type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 138/92 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 17/min. On physical exam, there is mild tenderness to palpation of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. There is 4/5 power throughout the lower extremity. Laboratory testing is shown. Serum: Na+: 137 mEq/L Cl-: 106 mEq/L K+: 2.9 mEq/L HCO3-: 18 mEq/L Glucose: 115 mg/dL Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL Urine pH: 5.6 Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.D: Begin potassium replacement therapy with dextrose

reason:
This patient's non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, alkaline urine, and history of a calcium phosphate kidney stone and rheumatoid arthritis are suggestive of type 1 (distal) renal tubular acidosis. The treatment of choice is alkali replacement (sodium bicarbonate).

Type 1 (distal) renal tubular acidosis results from impaired acid (H+) secretion in the distal nephron. Impaired acid secretion decreases the kidney's ability to acidify the urine, thus increasing the urine pH. Impaired acid secretion also results in potassium wasting resulting in hypokalemia. Acidemia causes the bone to release calcium phosphate which buffers the acid. The alkaline urine along with decreased citrate excretion (caused by acidemia) leads to a favorable environment to form calcium phosphate stones. Therefore, correction of metabolic acidosis is essential in managing this condition.

Palmer et al. review the evidence regarding the treatment of renal tubular acidosis. They discuss how this disease can be divided into types based on the location of the deficit. They recommend using alkali therapy in patients with distal renal tubular acidosis.

Incorrect Answers:
Answer A: Administering hydrochlorothiazide would be a treatment option for type 2 (proximal) renal tubular acidosis. Patients with this condition can have associated hypokalemia but would be expected to have an acidic urine pH (less than 5.5) after significant bicarbonate excretion.

Answer B: Administering intravenous insulin would further decrease the serum potassium and place the patient at risk of developing cardiac arrhythmia. This patient's most important concern is her renal tubular acidosis that is resulting in muscle weakness from hypokalemia. Her polyuria is caused by hypokalemia, as it decreases the kidney's responsiveness to antidiuretic hormone. Her serum glucose is also not significantly elevated to cause osmotic diuresis.

Answer D: The dextrose (in the replacement therapy with potassium) would trigger the pancreas to secrete insulin and would lead to an intracellular shift of potassium. This would not particularly improve extracellular potassium levels. Treatment should be aimed at addressing the root of the patient's symptoms. Potassium citrate can be administered in cases of severe hypokalemia and hypokalemia that persists after correcting the serum bicarbonate level.

Answer E: Increasing the methotrexate dose is not appropriate in this case. The patient's muscle weakness is more suggestive of hypokalemia secondary to type 1 renal tubular acidosis. She does not report symptoms of inflammatory arthritis (joint pain/stiffness that is worse in the morning and improves with use).

Bullet Summary:
Type 1 (distal) renal tubular acidosis is treated with alkali replacement (sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate).
raw_responses:
Step 1: Analyze the clinical findings.  
• The patient is a 56‐year‐old woman with a history of calcium phosphate kidney stones who now presents with progressive lower extremity weakness and increased urinary frequency.  
• Laboratory studies show hypokalemia (K⁺: 2.9 mEq/L) and metabolic acidosis (HCO₃⁻: 18 mEq/L) with a near normal anion gap.  
• The history of calcium phosphate stones, hypokalemia, and metabolic acidosis is highly suggestive of distal renal tubular acidosis (RTA type 1). In this condition, the distal tubules cannot adequately acidify the urine, leading to kidney stone formation and electrolyte disturbances.  

Step 2: Consider the treatment options.  
A. Hydrochlorothiazide – A thiazide diuretic would worsen hypokalemia.  
B. Intravenous insulin – Used for treating hyperkalemia by shifting potassium intracellularly, not indicated in hypokalemia.  
C. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate – Might help correct acidosis, but if given before addressing hypokalemia, it can further lower the serum potassium level by driving K⁺ into cells.  
D. Begin potassium replacement therapy with dextrose – Appropriate for correcting hypokalemia, which is paramount given the associated muscle weakness, and dextrose can help mitigate potential adverse effects of potassium infusion.  
E. Increase methotrexate dose – There is no link between methotrexate dose adjustment and the patient’s current electrolyte disturbance.  

Step 3: Final answer with reasoning.  
The patient’s presentation (muscle weakness, history of kidney stones, metabolic acidosis, and hypokalemia) points toward a diagnosis of distal renal tubular acidosis. The most important immediate management step is to address her symptomatic hypokalemia. Administering potassium—ideally with dextrose to avoid complications related to the infusion—is the most appropriate choice.

Final Answer: D. Begin potassium replacement therapy with dextrose.

Step 1: Analyze the patient’s presentation.  
• The patient is a 56-year-old woman with progressive muscle weakness (especially in the lower extremities), increased urinary frequency, and a history of calcium phosphate kidney stones.  
• Her labs reveal hypokalemia (K⁺ = 2.9 mEq/L) and metabolic acidosis (HCO₃⁻ = 18 mEq/L).  
• The urine pH is 5.6, which is inappropriately high for someone with metabolic acidosis.  

Step 2: Reach a diagnosis.  
• The combination of metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, and a relatively high urine pH suggests distal renal tubular acidosis (Type I RTA).  
• Distal RTA leads to an inability to excrete hydrogen ions, resulting in acidosis, and it predisposes patients to calcium phosphate kidney stones.  

Step 3: Consider the management options.  
• In the setting of distal RTA with hypokalemia, the immediate concern is the low potassium, which is contributing to her muscle weakness.  
• Correcting potassium is critical. Although bicarbonate therapy is also used to treat the acidosis seen in distal RTA, initiating intravenous sodium bicarbonate without addressing the hypokalemia may worsen the potassium deficit by causing further intracellular shifts of potassium.  

Step 4: Evaluate the answer choices.  
A. Administer hydrochlorothiazide – This is used for specific types of hypercalciuria, but it’s not appropriate for treating hypokalemia with metabolic acidosis.  
B. Administer intravenous insulin – Insulin drives potassium into cells, which would further lower serum potassium and is contraindicated.  
C. Administer intravenous sodium bicarbonate – Although bicarbonate can correct the acidosis, using it alone in a hypokalemic patient can exacerbate hypokalemia.  
D. Begin potassium replacement therapy with dextrose – This directly addresses the hypokalemia, which is likely the cause of her muscle weakness, and dextrose helps mitigate the risk of rapid intracellular shift of potassium.  
E. Increase methotrexate dose – There is no connection between methotrexate dosing and the current clinical picture.

Step 5: Provide the final answer.  
The most appropriate next step is to begin potassium replacement therapy with dextrose. 

Final Answer: D. Begin potassium replacement therapy with dextrose.

question: A 59-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for abdominal pain and foul-smelling diarrhea that has persisted for the past 2 years. The patient has a medical history of alcoholism and has been admitted to the hospital multiple times for withdrawal, abdominal pain, and traumatic injuries from his drinking. The patient states that his last drink was more than 1 year ago. His temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam reveals a non-tender, non-distended abdomen. Laboratory studies are notable for a serum calcium of 7.0 mg/dL. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen is performed as seen in Figure A. A Sudan Black stain of the patient’s stool is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for the underlying cause of this patient’s diarrhea?
reason:
This patient with a history of alcoholism is presenting with steatorrhea (foul-smelling diarrhea that stains with Sudan Black, a stain that detects fat in the stool), hypocalcemia, and findings suggestive of chronic pancreatitis on CT scan (inflammatory changes and calcification). His steatorrhea can be improved with the administration of proton pump inhibitors such as pantoprazole.

Chronic pancreatitis is a sequela that occurs after repeated bouts of acute pancreatitis. It can occur secondary to alcoholism or gallstones, and it may present with chronic abdominal pain, hypocalcemia, and signs of malnutrition and weight loss. Malnutrition and weight loss occur secondary to the pancreas’ inability to produce pancreatic enzymes which leads to poor nutrient absorption. Lack of lipase can lead to fat wasting in the stool, steatorrhea, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiency (A, D, E, and K). The management of chronic pancreatitis is the cessation of the underlying cause, pancreatic enzyme replacement, and the administration of proton pump inhibitors. Proton pump inhibitors help with steatorrhea by increasing the pH as low pH inactivates pancreatic enzymes.

Singh et al. review the diagnosis and management of chronic pancreatitis. The authors find that the diagnosis can be secured by typical findings on CT or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) including pancreatic calcifications, ductal dilatation, and pancreatic atrophy. The authors recommend the use of endoscopic ultrasound in securing the diagnosis in patients with equivocal imaging findings and a high index of suspicion, such as patients with repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis.

Figure/Illustration A is a CT scan of the abdomen demonstrating calcifications and chronic inflammatory injury (red arrows) suggesting a diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis.

Incorrect Answers:
Answer A: Ciprofloxacin or ceftriaxone is the appropriate management of infectious diarrhea from a bacterial organism. This usually presents with fever, as well as bloody or purulent diarrhea. In general, young and healthy patients who are able to hydrate themselves should not be given antibiotics, even for infectious diarrhea. Elderly patients, immunosuppressed patients, or patients with symptoms that do not improve spontaneously should be managed with a stool culture and antibiotics.

Answer B: Loperamide is an anti-diarrheal agent that could be used for irritable bowel syndrome to decrease bowel motility and improve symptoms of diarrhea. Loperamide and other antidiarrheals should never be used for infectious causes of diarrhea as they will delay the fecal shedding of the organism or virus and could prolong symptoms.

Answer C: Oral rehydration is recommended for any patient with diarrhea and signs of volume depletion and is preferred to IV fluids as the integrity of the gut is protected. This patient’s diarrhea is likely caused by his chronic pancreatitis; thus, oral rehydration may be indicated but does not address the underlying cause of this patient’s diarrhea.

Answer E: Rifaximin is an antibiotic that targets gut flora and can decrease enteric flora and treat conditions such as small bowel bacterial overgrowth. Small bowel bacterial overgrowth presents in patients with conditions such as diabetic gastroparesis or scleroderma secondary to decreased bowel motility causing bacterial overgrowth and profuse diarrhea. Treating the underlying cause in addition to rifaximin will eliminate the excess bacteria.

Bullet Summary:
Proton pump inhibitors should be given in patients with persistent diarrhea in the setting of chronic pancreatitis to prevent the inactivation of pancreatic enzymes.
raw_responses:
Let’s break down the case:

• The patient is a 59‐year‐old man with a long history of alcohol abuse who now complains of chronic abdominal pain and foul‐smelling diarrhea for 2 years.
• His CT scan (Figure A) is provided; in a patient with chronic alcohol abuse, CT images often reveal the “chain‐of‐lakes” appearance (irregular pancreatic duct with calcifications) seen in chronic pancreatitis.
• His stool is positive on a Sudan Black stain, meaning there is fat in the stool (steatorrhea). In chronic pancreatitis, the pancreas fails to release enough enzymes (eg, lipase) for proper fat digestion.
• His low serum calcium (7.0 mg/dL) is also seen in malabsorption syndromes—especially when unabsorbed fatty acids bind calcium.

Putting these factors together, the patient has chronic pancreatitis leading to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, causing fat malabsorption (steatorrhea) and secondary hypocalcemia.

The treatment that directly targets this underlying issue is pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT). This therapy helps digest fats and other nutrients and thus improves the malabsorption.

Now, let’s examine the provided options:
 A. Ciprofloxacin – an antibiotic used for bacterial infections.
 B. Loperamide – an anti‐motility agent that merely reduces diarrhea.
 C. Oral rehydration – supportive therapy for dehydration.
 D. Pantoprazole – a proton pump inhibitor used for acid-related disorders.
 E. Rifaximin – an antibiotic, sometimes used for small intestinal bacterial overgrowth.
